causes: Qajar Persia occupied Herat, violating British strategic interests.
Herat was seen as a gateway to India, making British control critical.
The British East India Company (EIC) wanted to prevent Persian expansion into Afghanistan.
events_leading_up_to_war: Persia signed a treaty with Britain in 1853, promising not to interfere in Afghan affairs.
In 1856, Persia seized Herat, claiming historical rights over the city.
Britain saw this as a direct threat to India and declared war.

result.general: British victory; Persia forced to withdraw from Herat.

treaties.name: Treaty of Paris (1857)
terms: Persia recognized Afghan sovereignty over Herat.
Persia had to withdraw from territories occupied during the war.
Trade agreements between Britain and Persia were adjusted in Britain's favor.

territorial_changes: Herat remained under Afghan control, preventing Persian expansion.

allies: Afghan forces under Dost Mohammad Khan (unofficial support)
Russian Empire (provided diplomatic but not military support)

private_military_companies_and_mercenari.name: British East India Company (EIC) Army
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.role: The EIC, a corporate entity, led the invasion using Indian troops.
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.tactics: Used superior naval power and rapid amphibious assaults.

private_military_companies_and_mercenari.name: Persian Tribal Mercenaries
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.role: Qajar Persia hired local warriors to bolster defenses in key regions.
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.tactics: Used hit-and-run tactics but struggled against modern British weaponry.

British_Empire: Major General Sir James Outram (Commander of British Forces)
Naval Captain Henry Keppel (Led Royal Navy assaults)

British_Empire.troops: 7,000+ (East India Company soldiers, British regulars, and sepoys)
British_Empire.navy: Multiple Royal Navy warships, including HMS Semiramis
British_Empire.tactics: Combined naval bombardment with rapid land invasions.

Qajar_Persia.navy: Small Persian fleet with minimal combat capability.
Qajar_Persia.tactics: Defensive warfare, relying on fortified cities and ambushes.

British_Empire.dead_and_wounded: Several hundred British and Indian casualties.
British_Empire.destruction: Minimal; British forces quickly overwhelmed Persian defenses.

Qajar_Persia.dead_and_wounded: Over 1,000 Persian soldiers killed or wounded.
Qajar_Persia.destruction: Significant damage to Persian coastal fortifications.

major_battles.name: Battle of Bushire
major_battles.description: British forces captured the Persian coastal city of Bushire, cutting off Persian supply lines.
major_battles.outcome: British victory, establishing a foothold for further operations.

major_battles.name: Battle of Khushab
major_battles.description: Decisive land battle where British and Indian troops defeated Persian forces in southern Iran.
major_battles.outcome: British victory, leading to the Persian surrender.

texts.name: East India Company Military Records
texts.author: EIC officials
texts.details: Detailed accounts of troop movements and battle strategies.

texts.name: Persian War Chronicles
texts.author: Qajar government scribes
texts.details: Accounts of Persian resistance and diplomatic negotiations.

archaeological_evidence.description: Remnants of Persian coastal defenses destroyed by British bombardment.
Rifles and artillery used by British and Indian troops.

political: The British East India Company dissolved in 1858, transferring power to the British Crown.
Persia lost influence over Afghanistan, strengthening British control in the region.
long_term_effects: Marked the last major military action by a corporate army (EIC).
Set the stage for future British interventions in Iran and the Persian Gulf.

military: One of the final wars fought by the **British East India Company before its dissolution.**
Highlighted the use of **corporate armies** in colonial conflicts.
political: Weakened Qajar Persia’s influence in Afghanistan and Central Asia.
Strengthened British dominance over **Persian Gulf trade routes.**
cultural: Persian nationalists later cited the war as an example of **colonial interference.**
Set a precedent for future **British interventions in Iranian politics.**
